My view: you need to reform your political system. No more lobbying that amounts to bribery of politicians. Bribery is poison to democracy. Policy should be decided on what the people want, not what a tiny minority of wealthy elites want.

http://www.upiasia.com/Politics/2009/09/25/lobbying_bribery_the_american_way/5999/

Lobbyists in the second quarter of this year alone have spent US$166 million to shoot this initiative down. By the time it comes to a vote in Congress, costs may be anywhere from US$4-500 million. This is a tremendous sum of cash going into politicians’ pockets.

item.description:
@yakman wrote:

Frell, you forgot the Bush tax cuts for the rich. It’s why Reagan and Bush ended with deficits but Clinton ended with a surplus.

Projected 2015 shortfall: $418 billion.

Savings:
Reduce military to pre-Iraq War size and further reduce troops in Asia and Europe: $25 billion
Reduce Navy and Air Force fleets: $19 billion
Cancel or delay some weapons programs: $19 billion
Reduce noncombat military compensation and overhead: $23 billion
Reduce the number of troops in Iraq and Afghanistan to 30,000 by 2013: $86 billion
Return the estate tax to Clinton-era levels: $50 billion
Kill the Bush tax cuts: $226 billion
Payroll tax: Subject some incomes above $106,000 to tax: $50 billion
Millionaire’s tax on income above $1 million: $50 billion
Reduce mortgage deduction and others for high-income households: $25 billion
Carbon tax: $40 billion
Bank Tax: $73 billion

Total savings: $763 billion

And that doesn’t even address corporate welfare. And you’ll notice I didn’t fuck over the states, people on Medicare, and people on Social Security either.

Now, you’re in charge of the nation’s finances. Make your own plan for closing the 2015 and 2030 budget gaps, then share it online.
